Article.ArticleTitle: The reaction of hydrated iodide I(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sup>-</sup> with ozone: a new route to IO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> products.

AbstractText: We report on an experimental characterization of the isolated reaction of hydrated iodide I(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sup>-</sup> with ozone O<sub>3</sub> at room temperature performed using a radio-frequency ion trap combined with a quadrupole mass spectrometer. Contrary to the oxidation reaction of the bare I<sup>-</sup> ion, the hydrated iodide I(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sup>-</sup> primarily reacts to form I<sup>-</sup> and IO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> with significant absolute reaction rate constants of 2.0 ± 0.3 × 10<sup>-10</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> molecule<sup>-1</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> and 2.5 ± 0.3 × 10<sup>-10</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> molecule<sup>-1</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> while direct pathways to IO<sup>-</sup> and IO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> are much weaker. Quantum chemical calculations indicate that in aqueous phase and for atmospherically relevant temperatures, the presence of hydrated iodides are favored over bare I<sup>-</sup> ions, thus suggesting that the chemistry of the hydrated ions is relevant for understanding and modeling atmospheric processes at the air-water interface.
